{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3383405,"name":"Paul Bansek","username":"bansekp","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/58956e/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-10T05:17:19.939Z","cooked":"

IMG_59401536×2048 371 KB

Last year was the first year we used swerve and it was a big learning curve for both electrical and programming. We used a set of 10 wago connectors on top of each module to connect all the canbus and power for the cancoder for a more compact and easier swap if needed. In one match, one of the wago levers got pulled up and we had random disconnects with the drive system canbus.

This year we wanted a more robust way to connect our modules up but still make it quick to swap them. Our idea was to design a board that can sit on top.

We set objectives/goals for a board:

  • Able to fit on top of the swerve module but not be taller than the cancoder

  • Use SMD 1206 components to help keep the board small

  • Connect the canbus wires from the motors and cancoder to it

  • Be able to terminate the canbus network with a built-in 120ohm resistor

  • Be able to daisy chain the power for the cancoders so less wires have to go back to the VRM

  • Have each board have a resettable fuse that if one cancoder shorts, the rest on the circuit are not affected

  • Have status LEDs for easy troubleshooting

First step was designing the circuit:

Schematic1024×791 29 KB

Next was designing the layout:

  • We went with Molex MicroClasp(55935) connectors for their 90 degree board connections, latching system, and small foot print.
  • To make it simple, 2 pin connectors for power and 4 pin connectors for canbus.
  • For the resettable fuse, we found that we needed a 100mA fuse to power an status LED and a single cancoder.
  • 1k resistors for the LEDs and a 120 ohm resistor for the termination of the canbus
  • First thought was to use a switch for turning on/off the termination resistor. Worried that switch could easily change states when the robot was impacted, we settled with using a 2x3 header pins and jumpers

We calculated that a .02in Trace width is more than enough for canbus and pass power for four cancoders.

Track Width2304×1296 78 KB

This was the end result after multiple revisions:

IMG_62481536×2048 316 KB

Board_Descriptions1920×1080 98.2 KB

Overall_Wiring2304×1296 413 KB

The CAD team incorporated the board into a custom cover with holes to see the LEDs and openings for wires:

IMG_59301536×2048 354 KB

We went to two regionals this year using the boards. Passed inspections and had no issues with them.

Have any questions, feel free to ask.

We used JLCPCB to make our boards

Files:
FRC2252_Swerve_Board_Files.zip (1.9 MB)
FRC2252_Swerve_Board_JLCPCB.zip (30.2 KB)

Three of the resistors and the PTC resettable fuse are soldered on the bottom of the board. Doing that made room for the status LEDs and for the termination jumpers on top while keeping the board small

Would it not have been better to have the motors connect to the CAN bus through the board rather than daisy chained to each other? If something were to happen to one of the motor can wires, your entire can bus goes down, right?

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-05-29T02:37:04.229Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":385,"readers_count":384,"score":82.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":465800,"topic_slug":"mavericks-2252-introduces-all-in-one-swerve-electrical-board","display_username":"Tim Winters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":55260,"username":"bansekp","name":"Paul Bansek","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/58956e/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19820,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"78 AIR Strike Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/mavericks-2252-introduces-all-in-one-swerve-electrical-board/465800/8","custom_user_title":"78 AIR Strike Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3393053,"name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","username":"nuclearnerd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-29T02:46:36.019Z","cooked":"

A pass-in, pass-out wago connector for the motor power leads might have been nice too. That way when replacing the module you make all your disconnections at the same place.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-05-29T02:46:36.019Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":377,"readers_count":376,"score":80.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":465800,"topic_slug":"mavericks-2252-introduces-all-in-one-swerve-electrical-board","display_username":"Brendan Simons, 5406","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22221,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/mavericks-2252-introduces-all-in-one-swerve-electrical-board/465800/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3393384,"name":"Paul Bansek","username":"bansekp","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/58956e/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-29T21:29:26.278Z","cooked":"
ArchdukeTim:

Is there more than one?

I thought you might be talking about the adapter board that bolts to the krakens. That does have the power and canbus connections for a cancoder. Our team didnt like having those connections so close to the ground. seemed to easy to get damaged or pulled out.

To your original question, the canbus wires of the drive and turn motors and the cancoder are daisy chained thru the board we designed. With any canbus network, if a wire does get damaged or removed, the network goes down.

Last season we used wagos to connect the wires but we had one latch get lifted and caused random disconnents of the network. By going to this board with latched connectors, we had no issues on the canbus network all season. We use two canbus networks, one dedicated to the drive system and the other for the rest of the motors and sensors.

I hope that answers your questions

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-05-29T21:29:26.278Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":303,"readers_count":302,"score":80.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":465800,"topic_slug":"mavericks-2252-introduces-all-in-one-swerve-electrical-board","display_username":"Paul Bansek","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55260,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/mavericks-2252-introduces-all-in-one-swerve-electrical-board/465800/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3393389,"name":"Paul Bansek","username":"bansekp","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/58956e/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-29T21:40:22.026Z","cooked":"

We used krakens for drive and falcons for turn. the krakens had a board on them with the anderson powerpole 45A connectors. We just ran the power straight to that board. With the falcons, we have the same connectors on the leads. we ran the power up to the motor and plug it in and zip tied the excess wire from the leads together. Those connections were pretty close that we didnt see needing them next to the board. i do like the idea of everything in one spot. Are the wagos part of the board or just next to it?

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-05-29T21:40:22.026Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":264,"readers_count":263,"score":72.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":465800,"topic_slug":"mavericks-2252-introduces-all-in-one-swerve-electrical-board","display_username":"Paul Bansek","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":22221,"username":"nuclearnerd","name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55260,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/mavericks-2252-introduces-all-in-one-swerve-electrical-board/465800/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3393412,"name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","username":"nuclearnerd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-29T23:23:50.122Z","cooked":"
bansekp:

Are the wagos part of the board or just next to it?

Could be either - your choice

ill have to see what is out there. if the board is not passing the power/current thru it for the motors, the design and manufacturing of it would stay low and simple

With any canbus network, if a wire does get damaged or removed, the network goes down.

This is not true. If the motors are connected to a main bus line separately then that motor’s can wires getting cut would only drop that motor.

Here, M1 and M2 are two motors connected separately to the bus using only one twisted pair of CAN wires.

       M1              M2
      H  L            H  L
      |  |            |  |
---------|---------------|----------- H
         |               |
------------------------------------- L
